primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Investigation of MERS-CoV seropositivity among Umrah visitors from the Çorum Region of Turkey
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
Forty patients who were admitted to our hospital’s Infectious
Diseases Clinics with upper respiratory tract complaints, and
who had also previously been in Saudi Arabia within 15 days
from January 1st to the 31st of October 2015 were included in
this study
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff:
The results ≤0.8 were considered as negative,
≥1.1 were as positive, 0.8-1.1 were suspected

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus in dromedary camels: an outbreak investigation
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: All camels present on the premises where the two men with recorded two cases of laboratory confirmed MERS-CoV had been in contact with the animals

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Comparative Serological Study for the Prevalence of Anti-MERS Coronavirus Antibodies in High- and Low-Risk Groups in Qatar
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: In total, 4858 plasma samples were analyzed in this study. Samples were distributed as follows: 4719 plasma samples were collected from BD during previous studies [16–20] over a period of five years (2012-2016; age: 19-88 years; mean age 37 years), 135 plasma samples were collected from individuals that were in CC to four CP (age: 14-49 years; mean age 31 years), and four plasma samples were collected from CP (age: 30-70 years; mean age 52). The CC individuals represented the patient’s family members, healthcare workers, and camel farm coworkers. Samples from CC were collected within the first week of the patient’s admission to hospital. This study was approved by Qatar University-IRB Review Exemption No. QU-QU-IRB 622-E/16.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Risk Factors for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus Infection among Camel Populations, Southern Jordan, 2014-2018
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The final 53 herds included in the study were recruited through local contacts of government veterinarians working in the study area. We sampled <12 camels per herd; in herds of <12, we sampled all camels, subject to accessibility and owner permissions.

primaryEstimateInfo.state: Guelmim-Oued Noun; Laâyoune-Sakia El Hamra; Dakhla-Oued Ed-Dahab
primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) neutralising antibodies in a high-risk human population, Morocco, November 2017 to January 2018
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Human blood sample collection was carried out over the 3 months from November 2017 through January 2018. A convenience sampling strategy was used to sample the different risk groups which led to blood samples being collected from 156 camel herders, 137 camel slaughterhouse (abattoir) workers and 186 individuals from the general population. The administrative regions of Guelmim-Oued Noun, Laâyoune-Sakia El Hamra and Dakhla-Oued Ed-Dahab were selected for study because 83.2% of all dromedary camels in Morocco are in these three regions [15].
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: The manufacturer recommends cut-off ratios of < 0.8 be interpreted as negative, ≥ 0.8 and < 1.1 as borderline, and ≥ 1.1 as positive. Because subsequent publications suggested a lower ELISA cut-off of ratio ≥ 0.3 for screening purposes for the selection of sera to be confirmed by neutralisation tests, we have also included ELISA optical density (OD) ratios of ≥ 0.3 in our analysis [9

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Lack of detection of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus in mild and severe respiratory infections in Catalonia, northeastern Spain
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Barcelona Centre for International Health Research
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: For our study, we selected cases of mild respiratory infections attending the primary-care centres as well as patients with severe febrile respiratory syndromes admitted to our hospital who underwent bronchoalveolar lavage

primaryEstimateInfo.state: Guelmim-Oued Noun; Laâyoune-Sakia El Hamra; Dakhla-Oued Ed-Dahab

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Respiratory virus detection in returning travelers and pilgrims from the Middle East
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
For the present study, we decided to use the latest definition to classify patients retrospectively. This definition [
10
] contains:

1/each person who travelled or lived, in a restricted list of countries (i. e. Saudi Arabia, Bahrein, United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Yemen, Iraq and Jordan), who presented within 14 days after the return:
-
signs of acute distress respiratory syndrome (ARDS)

-
or signs of pulmonary parenchyma infection confirmed by a thoracic radiography with fever ≥38 °C and cough

2/each contact of a possible or confirmed case who presented an acute respiratory infection within 14 days following the last contact with an infected patient.

3/each person who worked in or was admitted to a hospital in the restricted list of countries and who presented an acute respiratory infection within 14 days following the last contact with the institution.

4/each person who was in contact with camels or related products (non pasteurized milk, raw meat, urine) in a restricted list of countries and who presented an acute respiratory infection within 14 days.
primaryEstimateInfo.testProducerOther: Multiple producers. See Table 1 and methods

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Epidemiological investigation of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus in dromedary camel farms linked with human infection in Abu Dhabi Emirate, United Arab Emirates
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: All animals in 6 farms in Abu Dhabi

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Etiology of severe community-acquired pneumonia during the 2013 Hajj-part of the MERS-CoV surveillance program
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Global Center for Mass Gatherings Medicine
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Sputum samples were collected from all pilgrims admitted to 15 healthcare facilities in the cities of Makkah and Medina, Saudi Arabia, who were diagnosed with severe CAP on admission, presenting with bilateral pneumonia.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff:
A sample was confirmed MERS-CoV-positive if both RT-PCR assays were positive, as per current recommendations.
14

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus in dromedary camels: an outbreak investigation
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: All camels present on the premises where the two men with recorded two cases of laboratory confirmed MERS-CoV had been in contact with the animals

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) Seropositive Camel Handlers in Kenya
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Slaughterhouse workers and camel herders were recruited in Isiolo and Laikipia and slaughterhouse workers only in Machakos. These areas represent rural arid and semi-arid regions in Kenya where camels are kept and/or where camel slaughterhouses are located. Isiolo and Laikipia counties are in the arid and semi-arid northern region of Kenya and are inhabited by pastoral communities who keep camels as part of their livelihoods. Camels are transported to slaughterhouses in Isiolo, Laikipia and Machakos counties.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Samples with an extinction ratio of 0.3 were considered positive as previously described [7].

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Seroepidemiology for MERS coronavirus using microneutralisation and pseudoparticle virus neutralisation assays reveal a high prevalence of antibody in dromedary camels in Egypt, June 2013
MERS-CoV, influenza and other respiratory viruses among symptomatic pilgrims during 2014 Hajj season
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
Pilgrims presenting with acute severe respiratory tract symptoms and
suspected for MERS‐CoV infection at seven healthcare facilities in
Makkah, Mina, and Arafat

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Influenza virus but not MERS coronavirus circulation in Iran, 2013–2016: Comparison between pilgrims and general population
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Arriving pilgrims at Emam Khomeini Airport in Tehran with severe acute respiratory infections

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Genetic Evidence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-Cov) and Widespread Seroprevalence among Camels in Kenya
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The four camel breed types in Kenya sampled in this study were from historical and recent camel rearing tribes (Mburu et al.2003). Therefore, based on the geographical division of breed types, the 13 counties were grouped into five groups. For human sampling, high-risk groups such as camel herders and their immediate families were targeted. Sampling mainly focused on high-risk locations such as around watering points and common browsing locations that attract several herds of camels from different regions.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle east respiratory syndrome coronavirus in dromedaries in Ethiopia is antigenically different from the Middle East isolate EMC
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Dromedaries in the Afar region of Ethiopia
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Specimens showing neutralization at more than 20-fold dilution relative to the negative control were considered positive for MERS-CoV infection

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) RNA and Neutralising Antibodies in Milk Collected According to Local Customs from Dromedary Camels, Qatar, April 2014
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Dromedary camels in three barns at the Al Shahaniya barn complex and dromedary camels from a milking herd in the Dukhan area, Qatar

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Presence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus antibodies in Saudi Arabia: a nationwide, cross-sectional, serological study
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Expatriate slaughterhouse workers in Makkah
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Optical density ratio of at least 0.3 for ELISA, reciprocal titre of at least 20 on PRNT50 (50% plaque reduction)

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Low-Level Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus among Camel Handlers, Kenya, 2019
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We enrolled participants on a rolling basis from 32 camel-owning households in Marsabit County, northern Kenya. We defined a camel handler as any person in the household who had contact with camels.
primaryEstimateInfo.symptomDefinition: Respiratory symptoms (fever, running nose, cough, nasal stuffiness, sore throat, chest pain)

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Event based surveillance of middle east respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) in Bangladesh among pilgrims and travelers from the middle east: An update for the period 2013–2016
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: From October 2013 to June 2016 pilgrims and people returning from the Middle East presented with respiratory symptoms and having an epidemiological link were enrolled through active screening at the point of entry. After risk assessment by the medical team, suspected patients were admitted to the Kurmitola General Hospital isolation unit. In addition, travelers arriving with no clinical presentation received a health card mentioning the sign and symptoms of MERS-CoV infection. Self reported cases who developed symptoms within 14 days of arrival were included in sample collection along with admitted patients
primaryEstimateInfo.testProducerOther: TaqMan, Centers for Disease and Control kit #KT0136
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: A positive test result was defined as a well-defined exponential fluorescence curve that crossed the threshold within 45 cycles

humanCountriesOfTravel.country: occupied Palestinian territory - including east Jerusalem

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Lack of MERS coronavirus neutralizing antibodies in humans, Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Children hospitalized for lower respiratory tract infections

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: No Serologic Evidence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus Infection Among Camel Farmers Exposed to Highly Seropositive Camel Herds: A Household Linked Study, Kenya, 2013
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Camels in Marsabit County

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Laboratory Testing for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus, California, USA, 2013-2014
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: CDPH created a laboratory testing plan to detect or rule out MERS-CoV infection in patients who, after review by CDPH clinicians, met specific clinical and travel criteria, per CDC case definitions (10), to be considered a patient under investigation (PUI). Once a MERS PUI was identified, the patient’s specimens were transported from the hospital or local public health laboratory to CDPH in Richmond, California, for MERS-CoV testing.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Influenza virus but not MERS coronavirus circulation in Iran, 2013–2016: Comparison between pilgrims and general population
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Patients with severe acute respiratory infections in the general population

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Coronavirus Antibody Responses before COVID-19 Pandemic, Africa and Thailand
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Walter Reed Army Institute of Research
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We obtained serum and plasma specimens from 2 study cohorts in Africa and 1 in Thailand. Cohorts in Africa included the RV329 African Cohort Study (RV329/AFRICOS), which predominantly enrolled PLHIV with chronic infection, and study RV466 of the Joint West Africa Research Group (RV466/JWARG), which was designed to diagnose acute febrile illnesses in Nigeria. The cohort in Thailand was from the RV254 South East Asia Research Collaboration in HIV (RV254/SEARCH 010) study, which enrolls persons with acute HIV-1 infection. For negative controls, we used prepandemic plasma samples, including Zika Negative Plasma (SeraCare, https://www.seracare.comExternal Link), Pooled Normal Human Plasma (Innovative Research, https://www.innov-research.comExternal Link), and 2 human serum coronavirus panels, MSRM-CR1 and HMSRM-CR22 (BioIVT, https://bioivt.comExternal Link).

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: High Prevalence of MERS-CoV Infection in Camel Workers in Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The cohort for this study consisted of 30 CWs from Riyadh New Camel Market and 44 healthy controls recruited in Riyadh, KSA, and Iowa, USA. CWs were selected randomly, with the goal of including camel herders, handlers, and truck drivers. Camel herders feed, water, medicate, and milk camels. Camel handlers restrain, tighten (bind camels with ropes to prevent ambulation), and transport camels and have short but intense interactions with camels. Drivers help handlers and herders load camels into trucks. CWs control camels by placing their bare hands in the mouths of camels to avoid being bitten. Control samples of PBMCs were obtained from 14 anonymous donors at the University of Iowa and from 8 health care workers in KSA with no history of MERS exposure.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: The ELISA for MERS-CoV S-specific antibody was read as positive (>1.1), negative (<0.8), or borderline (0.8 to 1.1).

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Cross-sectional study of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus in humans and dromedary camels in Diyala, Iraq
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Human subjects included 90 participants who were subdivided into 3 groups; 40 individuals had close contact with camels, 20 were normal healthy individuals, and 30 were individuals who had visited KSA for Hajj or Umrah.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We collected samples from humans and animals at a live animal market, an outdoor slaughter area adjacent to that market, and the Tamboul Camel Research Centre (TCRC), all located in Tamboul, Sudan

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Seroprevalence of MERS-CoV in healthy adults in western Saudi Arabia, 2011-2016
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: A total of 7461 archived sera collected from healthy blood donors older than 17 years between 2011 and 2016 were retrieved. Demographic data including sex, age and nationality were obtained.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: All samples were tested in duplicates and samples with an optical density (OD) above the cut-off value of 0.26 were considered positive as previously described

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: High proportion of MERS-CoV shedding dromedaries at slaughterhouse with a potential epidemiological link to human cases, Qatar 2014
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Camels that presented for slaughter in Doha, Qatar

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Risk Factors for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus Infection among Camel Populations, Southern Jordan, 2014-2018
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We conducted multistage cross-sectional random sampling by using MoA-supplied lists of camel owners for Aqaba and Ma’an governorates organized by 4 local administrative areas (Aqaba East, Aqaba West, Ma’an East, and Ma’an West). We sampled <12 camels per herd; in herds of <12, we sampled all camels, subject to accessibility and owner permissions.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Cross-sectional study of MERS-CoV-specific RNA and antibodies in animals that have had contact with MERS patients in Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: This was part of a cooperative epidemiological response to the confirmed human cases of MERS with a history of animal contact. Notifications were issued by the Ministry of Health (MOH) associated with animals with a history of contact with MERS-patients

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Seroprevalence of SARS-CoV-2 among high-risk healthcare workers in a MERS-CoV endemic area
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: King Saud Bin Abdulaziz University for Health Sciences (KSAU-HS)
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: This is a cross-sectional seroprevalence study enrolling 420 high-risk HCWs who are working in three tertiary hospitals in Riyadh city. Those hospitals, include King Abdallah Specialist Children Hospital (KASCH), King Abdulaziz Medical City (KAMC), and Prince Mohammed bin Abdulaziz Hospital (PMAH), were dedicated to treat COVID-19 patients during this pandemic and MERS patients in the previous endemic.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Ratios above the cut-off-point 1.1 were considered positive as per the manufacturer’s instructions

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Occupational exposure to dromedaries and risk for MERS-CoV infection, Qatar, 2013–2014
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
We used 498 anonymized serum samples from persons in
Qatar with and without dromedary contact (online Technical Appendix, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/EID/article/21/8/15-
0481-Techapp1.pdf) and control serum from Europe (National Institute for Public Health and the Environment,
Bilthoven, the Netherlands; and University of Bonn, Bonn,
Germany). Sampling in Qatar was cleared by the Ethics
and Institutional Animal Care and Use Committees of the
Medical Research Center, Hamad Medical Corporation
(permit 2014-01-001). Samples from the Netherlands were
used in accordance with the Dutch Federation of Medical
Scientific Associations’ code of conduct for proper use of
human tissue. Samples from Germany were used in accordance with German national laws.
Of the 498 samples, 294 were f

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Screening for Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus infection in hospital patients and their healthcare worker and family contacts: a prospective descriptive study
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Global Centre for Mass Gatherings Medicine
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The KSA-MoH has implemented a pro-active early case detection and surveillance system for MERS-CoV. It recommends sending respiratory tract samples from critically ill patients admitted to hospitals with fever and lower respiratory tract infection symptoms. Screening for MERS-CoV is also recommended for family and healthcare worker (HCW) contacts of proven cases of MERS-CoV infection.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: High Prevalence of MERS-CoV Infection in Camel Workers in Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The cohort for this study consisted of 30 CWs from Riyadh New Camel Market and 44 healthy controls recruited in Riyadh, KSA, and Iowa, USA. CWs were selected randomly, with the goal of including camel herders, handlers, and truck drivers. Camel herders feed, water, medicate, and milk camels. Camel handlers restrain, tighten (bind camels with ropes to prevent ambulation), and transport camels and have short but intense interactions with camels. primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Surveillance and Testing for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus, Saudi Arabia, March 2016–March 2019
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We analyzed demographic and laboratory data for suspected and confirmed MERS-CoV cases reported to HESN during March 1, 2016–March 20, 2019 by using Microsoft Excel (https://www.microsoft.comExternal Link) and SAS 9.4 (https://www.sas.comExternal Link). For this analysis, we defined a suspected case as suspected MERS-CoV infection in a person with compatible symptoms during the study period, with >14 days separating illness episodes for persons in whom MERS-CoV infection is suspected more than once. We defined a confirmed case as laboratory confirmation of MERS-CoV infection in a person during the study period. By using MoH population estimates (7), we calculated rates of testing and positivity for the country, by local Health Affairs Directorate (HAD), and for Hajj pilgrims

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Countrywide Survey for MERS-Coronavirus Antibodies in Dromedaries and Humans in Pakistan
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
Human serum samples were obtained from hospitals, primary health care centres and blood banks from people older than 15 years of age
Dromedary camels
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Antibody titres of = 1:20 on neutralization assay

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Risk Factors for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus Infection among Camel Populations, Southern Jordan, 2014-2018

We sampled <12 camels per herd; in herds of <12, we sampled all camels, subject to accessibility and owner permissions.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Seroprevalence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Corona Virus in dromedaries and their traders in upper Egypt
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Camel traders in the southern part of Egypt involving Aswan, Asyut and New Valley

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus not detected in children hospitalized with acute respiratory illness in Amman, Jordan, March 2010 to September 2012
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: A prospective year‐round viral surveillance study in children <2 years admitted with respiratory symptoms and/or fever commenced on 16 March 2010 at Al Basheer Hospital, the main government‐run hospital and referral centre in Amman, Jordan, with 240 paediatric hospital beds and catchment of approximately one million persons (50% of the population). Subjects were enrolled 5 days per week (Sunday–Thursday) for approximately 30 months from March 2010 to September 2012
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Positive test results were assigned to samples generating well‐defined fluorescent curves that crossed the threshold within 45 cycles for any assay and were further investigated.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Risk Factors for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus Infection among Camel Populations, Southern Jordan, 2014-2018
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The final 53 herds included in the study were recruited through local contacts of government veterinarians working in the study area. We sampled <12 camels per herd; in herds of <12, we sampled all camels, subject to accessibility and owner permissions.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Sparse evidence of MERS-CoV infection among animal workers living in Southern Saudi Arabia during 2012
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Banked serum samples were collected using convenience sampling in July 2012 from 300 animal-exposed and 50 non-matched human controls residing in Jazan region, KSA, as part of a study investigating human Rift Valley fever exposure. The cross-sectional, convenience sample of human sera was chosen for its self-reported exposure to domestic animals, such as camels, as studies have documented increasing evidence that camels are a reservoir for MERS-CoV5, 6 and human MERS-CoV infections were later reported in the area.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: A specimen was considered as screening positive if the average of the three wells containing the sera exhibited a >50% reduction in luminescence in comparison to the luminescence negative (BSA) or no serum control.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Risk factors for serological evidence of MERS-CoV in camels, Kenya, 2016-2017
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Criteria for inclusion in this study were: counties with high camel densities, accessibility, security and interface areas for wildlife-livestock interactions.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Investigation of MERS-CoV seropositivity among Umrah visitors from the Çorum Region of Turkey
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
As a control group, 40 healthy people had been
selected who had no history of visiting risky areas and
respiratory tract complaints. Both suspicious and control
groups have been examined by infectious diseases specialists
and, their histories have been evaluated and recorded. From
all people included in this study, 10 ml blood samples were
collected, centrifuged, and stored at -20 °C
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff:
The results ≤0.8 were considered as negative,
≥1.1 were as positive, 0.8-1.1 were suspected

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Influenza is more common than Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) among hospitalized adult Saudi patients
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The case definition of suspected MERS-CoV was an acute febrile respiratory illness (fever, cough, or dyspnea) with radiographic evidence of pneumonia. We collected data for all suspected patients.

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Patients under investigation (PUIs) for MERS-CoV infection

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Persons working in the dromedary abattoirs

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Lack of middle east respiratory syndrome coronavirus transmission from infected camels

camelExposureLevelSubestimates.details: Community members not exposed to camels

primaryEstimateInfo.district: Aqaba East, Aqaba West, Ma'an East, Ma'an West
primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV exposure and risk factors for MERS-CoV ELISA seropositivity among members of livestock-owning households in southern Jordan: a population based cross-sectional study
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Livestock-owning households in four regions of Jordan (Aqaba East, Aqaba West, Ma’an East, and Ma’an West). Household membership was defined as either: (1) self-identifying as a household member and sleeping in the household the previous night; or (2) being a household employee.
primaryEstimateInfo.studyExclusionCriteria: Children younger than 5 years or individuals without capacity to provide informed consent
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: 2x the mean optical density of negative control sera

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Lack of MERS coronavirus neutralizing antibodies in humans, Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Plasma samples from men with a median age of 28 years (range 19–52 years) who donated blood at the hospital

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Seroepidemiology for MERS coronavirus using microneutralisation and pseudoparticle virus neutralisation assays reveal a high prevalence of antibody in dromedary camels in Egypt, June 2013
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Oart of an ongoing community-based seroepidemiological study on influenza virus among healthy subjects in Cairo and the Nile Delta region

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Laboratory Testing for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus, California, USA, 2013-2014
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: CDPH created a laboratory testing plan to detect or rule out MERS-CoV infection in patients who, after review by CDPH clinicians, met specific clinical and travel criteria, per CDC case definitions (10), to be considered a patient under investigation (PUI). Once a MERS PUI was identified, the patient’s specimens were transported from the hospital or local public health laboratory to CDPH in Richmond, California, for MERS-CoV testing.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Screening for Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus infection in hospital patients and their healthcare worker and family contacts: a prospective descriptive study
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Global Centre for Mass Gatherings Medicine
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The KSA-MoH has implemented a pro-active early case detection and surveillance system for MERS-CoV. It recommends sending respiratory tract samples from critically ill patients admitted to hospitals with fever and lower respiratory tract infection symptoms. Screening for MERS-CoV is also recommended for family and healthcare worker (HCW) contacts of proven cases of MERS-CoV infection.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Tested positive for both ORF1a and upE

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) neutralising antibodies in a high-risk human population, Morocco, November 2017 to January 2018
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Two hundred age-stratified sera collected in 2017 from blood donors in Hong Kong aged 16 to 69 years with no known exposure to dromedary camels were used as controls.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff:
The manufacturer recommends cut-off ratios of < 0.8 be interpreted as negative, ≥ 0.8 and < 1.1 as borderline, and ≥ 1.1 as positive. Because subsequent publications suggested a lower ELISA cut-off of ratio ≥ 0.3 for screening purposes for the selection of sera to be confirmed by neutralisation tests, we have also included ELISA optical density (OD) ratios of ≥ 0.3 in our analysis [9
Sera-positive at a titre of ≥ 1:20 in ppNT and ≥ 1:10 in PRNT90 assays were regarded as positive. Sera-positive at a titre of ≥ 1:20 in ppNT and ≥ 1:10 in PRNT50, but negative in PRNT90 assays were regarded as a borderline positive neutralisation result. All other sera were regarded as negative.

primaryEstimateInfo.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) — Surveillance and testing in North England from 2012 to 2019
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria:
From 1st September 2015 to 1st February 2019, returning travellers presenting to any hospital in the North West region with respiratory symptoms from the Middle East were risk assessed for potential MERS-CoV infection. This risk assessment was performed utilizing the PHE MERS criteria with a possible case defined as:

1. A person with severe acute respiratory infection requiring admission to hospital with symptoms of fever (≥38 °C) or history of fever and evidence of pulmonary parenchymal disease; and at least one of the following:
•
History of travel to, or residence in an area where infection with MERS-CoV could have been acquired in the 14-days before symptom onset

•
Close contact during the 14-days before onset of illness with a symptomatic confirmed case of MERS-CoV infection

•
Person is a healthcare worker based in ICU caring for patients with severe acute respiratory infection, regardless of travel or PPE use

•
Part of a cluster of two or more epidemiologically linked cases within a two-week period requiring ICU admission, regardless of history of travel


2. Acute influenza-like-illness symptoms (ILI), and contact with camels, camel environments or consumption of camel products in the 14-days prior to onset.

3. Acute respiratory illness (ARI) and contact with a confirmed case of MERS-CoV in the 14 days prior to onset.

Those meeting the PHE case definition were discussed with the Regional Infectious Diseases team and/or the Consultant Virologist and then tested for infection (
(PHE) PHE, 2018a
) (
Figure 1
).

humanCountriesOfTravel.country: occupied Palestinian territory - including east Jerusalem

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Investigation of anti-middle east respiratory syndrome antibodies in blood donors and slaughterhouse workers in Jeddah and Makkah, Saudi Arabia, Fall 2012
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Because of reports on potential exposures with livestock animals in MERS cases, workers from 2 slaughterhouses in Jeddah and 3 slaughterhouses in Makkah were investigated in October 2012. Slaughtered animals included cattle, camels, and sheep. The workers were aged 16–61 years, had worked in slaughterhouses for intervals ranging from 2 months to 36 years, and were from various countries

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Serological evidence of coronavirus infections in native hamadryas baboons (Papio hamadryas hamadryas) of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Native baboons of KSA that coexist with feral dogs

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Genetic Evidence of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-Cov) and Widespread Seroprevalence among Camels in Kenya
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: The four camel breed types in Kenya sampled in this study were from historical and recent camel rearing tribes (Mburu et al.2003). Therefore, based on the geographical division of breed types, the 13 counties were grouped into five groups. For human sampling, high-risk groups such as camel herders and their immediate families were targeted. Sampling mainly focused on high-risk locations such as around watering points and common browsing locations that attract several herds of camels from different regions.
primaryEstimateInfo.socioeconomicStatus: 89% had no education; 7% had primary school level; 4% had secondary or more (Table S1).

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Surveillance and Testing for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus, Saudi Arabia, April 2015-February 2016
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: In Saudi Arabia, persons who should be tested for MERS-CoV include suspect case-patients who meet at least 1 of 4 case definition categories (Technical Appendix Table). In brief, the categories are persons with community-acquired pneumonia (category I); healthcare-associated pneumonia (II); symptoms after exposure to a MERS-CoV case-patient (III); or unexplained febrile illness (IV). The case definition was revised in May 2014 (7); additional refinements were made in June 2015 (8). The 2015 definition included changes to the approach for testing children <14 years of age with nonsevere illness (testing is reserved for children with exposure to camels or camel products or to a confirmed or suspected MERS case-patient). In addition to suspected cases, testing is recommended for close contacts of persons with confirmed MERS-CoV infection, regardless of symptoms, and can also be requested at the discretion of an infectious disease consultant.
primaryEstimateInfo.symptomDefinition: healthcare-associated pneumonia (II); symptoms after exposure to a MERS-CoV case-patient (III); or unexplained febrile illness (IV)

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Risk Factors for MERS-CoV Seropositivity among Animal Market and Slaughterhouse Workers, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, 2014-2017
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: We conducted 3 rounds of worker serum sampling. The first round was conducted during May 11–14, 2014, and the second round during March 23–April 1 and May 7–13, 2015. During the first 2 rounds of sampling, all available workers at the market and public slaughterhouse were requested to provide a serum sample as part of a public health investigation. We conducted a third round of serum sampling during September 22–October 5, 2016, and March 20–23, 2017. The third round of sampling included workers at the market, public slaughterhouse, and the newly opened commercial slaughterhouse. All available workers were requested to provide serum samples, although participation was voluntary. Some, but not all, workers were repeatedly sampled, when feasible, during multiple rounds.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: ll serum samples with optical densities above assay cutoff were diluted serially, 4-fold, from 1:100 to 1:6,400, and used for endpoint titer determinations. Serum samples that were positive by N or S ELISA with titers at 1:400, 1:1600, or 1:6,400, plus 10% of samples negative by N or S ELISA at these titers, were tested by using microneutralization with live MERS-CoV performed in a Biosafety Level 3 laboratory, as previously described (26).

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Infections in travellers returning to Turkey from the Arabian peninsula: a retrospective cross-sectional multicenter study
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Haydarpasa Numune Training and Research Hospital
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Our inclusion criteria were adult patients (age over 15) who had acquired an infection during their trip to an Arabian Peninsula country, or who became symptomatic within 1 week of their return. Data were collected retrospectively between January 1, 2013 and March 1, 2015 across 15 Turkish referral centers with infectious diseases departments located in the main cities

These individuals had been submitted for blood donor eligibility screening at King Abdulaziz University Hospital, Jeddah, between January and December 2012.

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Our inclusion criteria were adult patients (age over 15) who had acquired an infection during their trip to an Arabian Peninsula country, or who became symptomatic within 1 week of their return. Data were collected retrospectively between January 1, 2013 and March 1, 2015 across 15 Turkish referral centers with infectious diseases departments located in the main cities

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Detection of multiple viral sequences in the respiratory tract samples of suspected Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus patients in Jakarta, Indonesia 2015-2016
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Clinical specimens were collected from a total of 13 hospitalized patients with suspected MERS-CoV infection in Prof. Dr. Sulianti Saroso IDH from July 2015 to December 2016. The majority of patients presented with pneumonia and symptoms including fever (≥37.5 °C), dyspnea, and cough. All patients had a history of travel to the Middle East <14 days prior to biological sampling.

humanCountriesOfTravel.country: occupied Palestinian territory - including east Jerusalem

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Cross-sectional survey and surveillance for influenza viruses and MERS-CoV among Egyptian pilgrims returning from Hajj during 2012-2015
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: Egyptian Ministry of Health and Population
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: A cross-sectional survey was conducted at Cairo International Airport among Egyptians returning from Hajj during the week following the end of Hajj each year from 2012 to 2015 (Table 1). A team from the MOHP sought to enroll a convenience sample of approximately 10% of pilgrims from each flight returning from Hajj and congregating at the airport carousels, regardless of age, sex, and illness status.

primaryEstimateInfo.state: Eastern Region of Abu Dhabi Emirate
primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Diversity of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronaviruses in 109 dromedary camels based on full-genome sequencing, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: All patients in Riyadh and Al-Qassim regions who had their samples tested at Riyadh regional lab during the study period were considered as suspected cases

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: The prevalence of MERS-CoV among military personnel and their families: A single-center study
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: A total of 35,203 sputum samples were collected from patients hospitalized at the King Fahd Armed Forces Hospital Jeddah, KSA. Patients were family members of military personnel, belonging to a triangular region consisting of three anchor cities: Jeddah, Al-Jumum, and Makkah of the western KSA. The three cities are about 50 km far away from each other. Additional samples were collected from a few healthcare workers (n = 5). All patients experienced fever and respiratory distress.
primaryEstimateInfo.symptomDefinition: 'respiratory distress' ": The clinical signs included fever, respiratory distress, and pneumonia in fatal cases.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: MERS-CoV in Camels but Not Camel Handlers, Sudan, 2015 and 2017

primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: Livestock-owning households in four regions of Jordan (Aqaba East, Aqaba West, Ma’an East, and Ma’an West). Household membership was defined as either: (1) self-identifying as a household member and sleeping in the household the previous night; or (2) being a household employee.
primaryEstimateInfo.studyExclusionCriteria: Children younger than 5 years or individuals without capacity to provide informed consent

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Comparative Serological Study for the Prevalence of Anti-MERS Coronavirus Antibodies in High- and Low-Risk Groups in Qatar
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: In total, 4858 plasma samples were analyzed in this study. Samples were distributed as follows: 4719 plasma samples were collected from BD during previous studies [16–20] over a period of five years (2012-2016; age: 19-88 years; mean age 37 years), 135 plasma samples were collected from individuals that were in CC to four CP (age: 14-49 years; mean age 31 years), and four plasma samples were collected from CP (age: 30-70 years; mean age 52). The CC individuals represented the patient’s family members, healthcare workers, and camel farm coworkers. Samples from CC were collected within the first week of the patient’s admission to hospital. This study was approved by Qatar University-IRB Review Exemption No. QU-QU-IRB 622-E/16.

primaryEstimateInfo.sourceTitle: Seroprevalence of SARS-CoV-2 among high-risk healthcare workers in a MERS-CoV endemic area
primaryEstimateInfo.insitutution: King Saud Bin Abdulaziz University for Health Sciences (KSAU-HS)
primaryEstimateInfo.studyInclusionCriteria: This is a cross-sectional seroprevalence study enrolling 420 high-risk HCWs who are working in three tertiary hospitals in Riyadh city. Those hospitals, include King Abdallah Specialist Children Hospital (KASCH), King Abdulaziz Medical City (KAMC), and Prince Mohammed bin Abdulaziz Hospital (PMAH), were dedicated to treat COVID-19 patients during this pandemic and MERS patients in the previous endemic.
primaryEstimateInfo.positiveCutoff: Ratios above the cut-off-point 1.1 were considered positive as per the manufacturer’s instructions
